abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Petroleum Exploration Promotion Project
            in Tunisia. The project's objectives were to provide
            the basis for increasing the rate of discovery and
            development of Tunisia's hydrocarbon resources through:
            (i) attracting further private sector participation in
            exploration of prospective open areas; (ii) strengthening
            Entreprise Tunisienne d'Activités Pétrolières,
            ETAP's  (Tunisian Petroleum Activity Company)technical
            capabilities to assess hydrocarbon potential; and (iii)
            providing, through state-of-the-art exploration data
            acquisition techniques, "leads" to induce
            international oil company (IOC) activity in open areas
            currently left unexplored.  Bank's performance was
            deficient. Borrower's performance was deficient. The
            key lessons learned were as follows: (i) lend only when all
            aspects of the institutional framework are satisfactory
            (managerial and technical capacity, administrative and
            regulatory framework), or the operation itself addresses the
            problems directly; (ii) rigorously evaluate borrower and
            guarantor commitment to small projects where the loan
            carries little leverage, and consolidate such small projects
            into a coherent sectoral operation; (iii) rigorously enforce
            critical covenants; (iv) use retroactive financing only
            under justified circumstances and under highly satisfactory
            institutional arrangements; and (v) make discussions of new
            projects contingent on resolution of problems on ongoing
            projects. Management should enforce early action to resolve
            issues appropriately.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Petroleum Exploration Promotion
            Project essentially involves an evaluation of the petroleum
            potential of the prospective areas in Tunisia based on the
            evaluation of existing geological and geophysical data,
            which will then be presented to the oil industry. The main
            components of the project are as follows : (i) a seismic
            program, which involves the reprocessing of existing data
            and the acquisition and processing of a further 1,000 kms of
            new data; (ii) consultants to conduct gravity and airmag
            surveys in the north of the country; (iii) equipment for
            extensive geologic and geochemical surveys; and (iv)
            computer software for seismic data processing and a systems
            analyst to introduce the new software packages. The project
            will also provide technical assistance for the preparation
            of a promotional package, the organization of promotional
            meetings, and to arrange meetings with potentially
            interested companies. Finally, the project will provide
            training to staff from ETAP (Entreprise Tunisienne
            d'Activities Petrolieres) in advanced exploration technologies.
